section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.rac_book_summary: Young children share the different ways they take care of the Earth. They know that every little thing they do each day can make a big difference!

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Rr, Ww, Jj Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: Say a word. Have children choose the matching card: Rabbit, ring, Wagon, wolf, Jacket, jam. Invite children to say rhymes for ring.
Play theme music and invite children to dance to celebrate our wonderful Earth. Then ask children to share ideas about why Earth is such a great place.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Earth Book written and illustrated by Todd Parr.
Pablo loves reading informational books so he can learn things. Let’s see how some children show us how to take care of the Earth.
Here’s a question to think about as I read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What small things can you do to save water and trees?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This little girl wants to make a BIG difference. Use your arms to show a big difference. Let’s find out about the little things she does.
Why does bringing your own bags to the store help to save paper? If you wanted to save paper, what could you do?
The paper we use comes from trees. This little boy lets us know that he saves paper because he loves trees. Can you tell me which animals love trees?
section.rac_body-text: Note if children correctly use subject-verb agreement. if not, model correct subject-verb agreement for them.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does turning off the faucet while brushing your teeth help to save water? Does this remind you of something you do?
Look at the faces on the children, the fish, and the whale. Why are they happy when the oceans stay blue?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What small things can you do to save water and trees?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I can use both sides of a paper.
I can bring my own bags to the store.
I can turn the faucet off while brushing my teeth.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about things to do to take care of Earth.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What can you do to save paper?
I can use both s______ (sides) of the paper.
I can use both sides of the paper.
What might you do to save water?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Improve sentence structure through conversation. When a child says something grammatically incorrect, model the correct way. Incorporate activities requiring them to repetitively use a correct grammar. Focus on one grammatical component to avoid overloading children with too many new concepts.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Take Responsibility for Materials and Jobs
section-block.rac_body-text: Ask “What would you do if . . .” questions to help children continue exploring how to be responsible for materials and jobs. What would you do if you spilled milk on the table? What would you do if someone left books on the floor? What would you do if your friend broke his crayon? (MB)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about the Mind Builder and see how children take responsibility when we revisit The Earth Book.
Clifford loves to find out what children think about and do to help their class community.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about ways children take care of and manage classroom materials.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How is this girl taking care of classroom materials? (MB)
What else might she do with paper in the classroom?
What classroom job might a child have at snack time that would help the class community? (MB)
What could this child do at school that she is doing at home to save energy? (MB)
What classroom job might this child have to help the class? (MB)
What are the children doing with these materials? In what ways do we recycle at school? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Assign children to three groups. Tell children that it is fun to use materials in new and different ways. Explain that today, they are going to measure a long sheet of paper. However, they are not going to use a ruler. Instead, provide them with straws, crayons, and sticky notes (make sure the items are all the same size). Ask children to work with their group partners to measure the paper with the straws, then the crayons, and then the sticky notes.
Call the groups together to share the results. (MB)
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about things to do to take care of the Earth.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: To ensure children take an active role in maintaining the classroom, assign jobs on a rotating basis. Jobs give children responsibilities and ownership in the classroom. Rotating jobs ensures everyone is sharing these responsibilities. Posting a list of jobs with movable names will clarify who is responsible for which job. (Hayes and Creange, 2001)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 4: Protect the Earth

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk about things that use the energy from electricity to make them go. Ideas may include computers, refrigerators, and lights.
Prepare a bag with items made of aluminum, paper, plastic, and glass. Have children take turns choosing an item and telling what it’s made of.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book The Earth Book by Todd Parr.
Pablo wants to know more about the little things we can do to take care of our world.
Think about this guiding question as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What can we do to save energy and recycle materials?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When they ride a bus or a bike, these people use less energy than if they ride in a car.
Why do you think they are smiling? Which word begins with the same sound as the words ring and rabbit?
What signal could you use to remind a friend to turn off the lights to save energy? Why are the girl, the snowman, and the polar bears all smiling?
We know about recycling. In which bin would you put a newspaper? A shampoo bottle? A glass jar? (MB)
This little girl wants Earth to have lots of water and trees. She wants everyone to have enough energy. And she wants everyone to recycle. Why is she so happy now?
What animals do you see on these pages? How does taking care of Earth help all these animals?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What can we do to save energy and recycle materials?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Recycle glass, plastic, paper, and aluminum.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen together as you work together to write about things to do to take care of Earth.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I can recycle glass, pl ______ (plastic), paper, and aluminum.
I can recycle glass, plastic, paper, and aluminum.
How do you recycle these materials?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: To develop science concepts, such as energy, children need to experience them in many contexts. They need to make a connection of new knowledge with what is known. To help children make these connections in different ways across the curriculum, incorporate science activities throughout the day’s activities.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 4: Protect the Earth

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about things that they do each day that help to take care of Earth. Tell children that on today’s poster they will see what other children do.
Describe what is happening and ask children if it’s time for Lights On (motion upward) or Lights Off (motion downward). For example, bedtime; time to read.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read You Can Help! It’s a poster with informational text.
Pablo the Parrot loves to read about ways of taking care of our home, Earth.
The Earth Book and You Can Help! both focus on what we can do to take care of the Earth. Let’s listen and make connections!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can we care for our world?
section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Protecting the Earth
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text of the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you find the picture that shows a child turning off the lights to save electricity? When might you turn off the lights in our room?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Can you find the picture that shows a child turning off the water? How can we save water in our classroom?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What sound does the word water begin with? Which letter makes the /w/ sound?
What are these children recycling?
Which pictures show things children made out of other things?
What is the same about what these children do and what the children do in The Earth Book?

section.rac_body-text: Assign children to groups of three. Provide each group with a clean and empty plastic bottle, drawing paper, and crayons. Tell children that they are going to think of ways they could reuse the bottle by making it into something else. They should brainstorm ideas with the group and then draw a picture that shows their ideas.
Provide a writing prompt about things they can do to protect the Earth and give ongoing feedback as children write.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Remember that all children bring something to the learning environment, and multilingual learners have knowledge, skills, competencies, and understandings that can be leveraged and built upon. The development of literacy depends on all four learning modalities. Provide opportunities for them to practice and use these modalities while learning content.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 4: Protect the Earth

section-block.rac_body-text: Engage children in singing about recycling to take care of our world. Sing these lyrics to the tune of “Twinkle Twinkle Little Star”: We recycle, we recycle. What we use, what we use. Glass and paper, plastic. Glass and paper, plastic. You should, too, You should, too.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book The Earth Book by Todd Parr.
Pablo learned so many things when we read this book of informational text!
This week we read about things to do to take care of our world. As we read the book one more time, think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What are some little ways we can help Earth?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: These children say, “I love the trees and I want the owls to have a place to live.” What other animals need and use trees?
These children say, “I love the fish and I want the ocean to stay blue.” Clap three times if you love the fish and want the ocean to stay blue.
The girl says, “I love the stars and I want the air to be clear so I can see them sparkle.”
Let’s pretend to look up and flick our fingers to show how the stars sparkle.
This girl says, “I love to walk barefoot in the grass and I don’t want to move to Mars!” What little things can you recycle?
We all want everyone to be happy and healthy on Earth. Let’s look at the 10 things on this list. Is there anything that is silly and doesn’t belong on this list?
section.rac_body-text: Discuss each item.
Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What are some little ways we can help Earth?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Possible answers:
Invite children to draw or write about things they can do to protect Earth and share their work with the class.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What can we do to help save trees?
Why does saving paper help save trees?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Exploring informational texts exposes young children to a wider range of vocabulary, enhances their language skills, and increases their knowledge of text structure and text features. Such texts also help children to develop background knowledge in many different content areas. These skills are crucial building blocks to literacy!
